description: This course provides an overview of the neurobiology of learning and memory, from cognitive to molecular neuroscience, including human, animal, cellular, and molecular studies of memory. Topics include amnesia, intellectual disability, exceptional intelligence, aging, and Alzheimer’s disease.
prereq_raw: upper-division standing and BILD 12 or COGS 107B or COGS 17 or PSYC 106 or PSYC 181 or PSYC 181GS or PSYC 2.

title: Psychology of Human Sexuality
description: This course provides an overview of human sexuality research including diversity of sexual behavior and identities, sex and gender development, intimate relationships, and sexual dysfunction. Recommended preparation: completion of PSYC 1, 2, or 106.
prereq_raw: upper-division standing.

title: Visual Cognition
description: This course provides an overview of high-level visual perception, and of how visual perception intersects with attention, memory, and concepts. Topics may include an introduction to the visual system with an emphasis on high-level visual regions; object recognition, face recognition, scene recognition and reading; visual attention, including eye movements during scene perception and during reading; and visual working memory.
prereq_raw: upper-division standing.

title: Psychology of Mindfulness and Well-being
description: This course provides a review of the scientific research surrounding the topic of mindfulness, which has been approached from multiple disciplines including Buddhism, positive psychology, cognitive behavioral therapy, and neuroscience. Because mindfulness is so multifaceted with many variables involved, the scientific study of mindfulness requires rigorous research methods and statistics, and for this reason a significant portion of the class focuses on these aspects.
prereq_raw: upper-division standing, COGS 14B or MATH 11 or PSYC 60, and COGS 14A or PSYC 70. Department approval.

title: Creativity
description: This course provides an overview of how to foster creativity in individuals, groups, and organizations. Themes that cut across all three levels are highlighted.
prereq_raw: upper-division standing.

title: Industrial Organizational Psychology
description: This course provides an examination of human behavior in industrial, business, and organizational settings. Topics include psychological principles applied to selection, placement, management, and training; the effectiveness of individuals and groups within organizations, including leadership and control; conflict and cooperation; motivation; and organizational structure and design.
prereq_raw: upper-division standing.

title: Drugs, Addiction, and Mental Disorders
description: This course provides an overview of the use, abuse, liability, and psychotherapeutic effects of drugs on humans.
prereq_raw: upper-division standing.

title: Adolescence
description: This course provides an overview of the period of human adolescence, including the physical, cognitive, social, and emotional changes that take place during this developmental transition.
prereq_raw: upper-division standing.

title: Illusions and the Brain
description: This course provides an examination of visual, auditory, and tactile illusions and examines how they arise from interactions between perceptual and cognitive systems.
prereq_raw: upper-division standing.

title: Choice and Self-Control
description: This course provides an overview of the experimental analysis of choice behavior, with an emphasis on the types of choice involved in self-control. A central interest will be the conditions under which decision-making is optimal.
prereq_raw: upper-division standing.

title: Psychology of Climate Crisis
description: This course provides tools for the student to think about the escalating climate crisis. Urgent action is needed at a large, societal scale to prevent the worst consequences of anthropogenic global heating. Better understanding the prospects for such action can come from human psychology. How do people arrive at their beliefs? What is the basis of denial and delay? How does belief flow to action? What kinds of actions can people take?
prereq_raw: upper-division standing.

title: Evolutionary Psychology
description: This course provides an overview of the forces that shaped the human brain and behavior over our evolutionary history. The first part of the course will provide the key background on evolutionary principles and human natural history. The second part of the course will delve into the origins of defining characteristics of human cognition, such as language and theory of mind, by drawing on our understanding of both human evolution and comparisons with our living nonhuman primate relatives.
prereq_raw: upper-division standing.

title: Development of Social Cognition
description: This course provides an overview of how children learn to reason about the social world. Topics may include theory of mind, social categorization and stereotyping, moral reasoning, and cultural learning. Recommended preparation: PSYC 101.
prereq_raw: upper-division standing.

title: Impulse Control Disorders
description: This course provides an overview of problems of impulse control, which are important features of major psychiatric disorders and also of atypical patterns of behavior including pathological gambling, compulsive sex, eating, exercise, and shopping. Topics include development, major common features, treatment, and neurobiological basis of impulse control disorders.
prereq_raw: upper-division standing.

title: Brain, Behavior, and Evolution
description: This course provides a survey of natural behaviors, including birdsong, prey capture, localization, electroreception and echolocation, and the neural system that controls them, emphasizing broad fundamental relationships between brain and behavior across species. Cross-listed with BIPN 189. Students may not receive credit for PSYC 189 and BIPN 189.
prereq_raw: upper-division standing, BILD 2 or COGS 101A or COGS 107B or PSYC 102 or PSYC 106.

title: Science of Parenting
description: This course provides an interdisciplinary overview of theories and scientific research on parenting. Topics may include family structure, parenting styles, attachment, discipline strategies, culture, and media. This course also takes a critical approach to the scientific evidence regarding the role of parents in child development. Topics may include behavior genetics, discipline, diet, sleep, the nature of learning, screen time, impulse control, and vaccination.
prereq_raw: upper-division standing.

title: Psychology of Sleep
description: This course provides an overview of the psychology of sleep, including sleep stages and their functions, neurological aspects of sleep, sleep across species and development, dreams and their interpretation, sleep disorders, and the role of sleep in learning and memory.
prereq_raw: upper-division standing.

title: Senior Seminar in Psychology
description: The Senior Seminar Program is designed to allow senior undergraduates to meet with faculty members in a small setting to explore an intellectual topic in psychology (at the upper-division level). Topics will vary from quarter to quarter. Senior Seminars may be taken for credit up to four times, with a change in topic, and permission of the department. Enrollment is limited to twenty students, with preference given to seniors.
prereq_raw: department approval and consent of instructor.

title: Topics in Psychology
description: Selected topics in the field of psychology. May be taken for credit three times as topics vary.
prereq_raw: upper-division standing and department approval.

title: Psychology Laboratory Topics
description: Selected laboratory topics in the field of psychology. May be taken for credit two times as topics vary. Open to the following majors only: PC26, PC28, PC29, PC30, PC31, PC32, PC33, PC34, CG32.
prereq_raw: upper-division standing, department approval, and PSYC 60 or COGS 14B or MATH 11 and PSYC 70 or COGS 14A.

title: Honors Thesis I
description: This course provides the opportunity for students to plan and carry out a research project under the guidance of the psychology faculty. Students will write a proposal for the research that they plan to conduct in 194B-C and will present this proposal to the class. Must be taken for a letter grade for the Psychology Honors Program.
prereq_raw: PSYC 110, PSYC 111A-B, department approval, psychology majors only, acceptance to the Honors Program.

title: Honors Thesis II
description: This course provides the opportunity for students to continue to carry out their research projects. Must be taken for a letter grade for the Psychology Honors Program.
prereq_raw: PSYC 110, PSYC 111A-B,   PSYC 194A, department approval, psychology majors only, acceptance to the Honors program.

title: Honors Thesis III
description: This course provides the opportunity for students to complete their research, write their honors thesis, and present their results at the Honors Poster Session. Must be taken for a letter grade for the Psychology Honors Program.
prereq_raw: PSYC 194A-B, department approval, psychology majors only, acceptance to the Honors program.

title: Statistical Computing and Inference from Data I
description: The first of a series of intensive courses in statistical computing to draw inferences from data. This course covers research design, causal inference, data wrangling, visualization, probability, statistical inference, and the general linear model.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Quantitative Methods in Psychology II
description: The second part of a series of intensive courses in statistical methods and the mathematical treatment of data, with special reference to research in psychology.
prereq_raw: PSYC 201A.

title: Quantitative Methods in Psychology III
description: The third part of a series of intensive courses in statistical methods and the mathematical treatment of data, with special reference to research in psychology.
prereq_raw: PSYC 201B.

title: Writing and Presenting Academic Research Papers
description: Instruction on organizing, writing, and presenting empirical research papers. Students will learn fundamentals of writing style, data presentation, and time management. This course is intended for psychology graduate students in service of preparation of their first-year papers and talks.
prereq_raw: psychology graduate students (major code: PC76 or PC78 or PC79), or consent of instructor.

title: Emotion
description: This seminar provides a selective overview of the scientific study of emotion. We will discuss various theoretical perspectives on emotion and will focus on specific topics such as emotion regulation, affect in social interactions, individual differences, and particular emotions (e.g., embarrassment, envy, and jealousy).
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Mathematical Modeling
description: This course is designed to teach the basics of mathematical modeling. Topics include when, why, and how to use signal detection theory (an essential theory for anyone interested in attention, perception, memory, or decision making), how to analyze reaction time distributions (instead of simply measuring mean RT), how to engage in the fine art of model comparison, and how to avoid creating models that are more complex than the data they seek to explain.

title: Judgment and Decision Making
description: This seminar examines issues in the psychology of judgment and decision making. Topics include the heuristics and biases approach, overconfidence, framing effects, intertemporal choice, and rationality.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: The Methods of Human Cognitive Neuroscience
description: Covers many of the neuroscience methods available to study human cognition, with emphasis on concepts of data analysis, and comparative assessment of the different methods (along with alternative nonhuman animal approaches), with an eye to pitfalls and interpretational limitations.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Proseminar in Computational Models of Mind
description: Computational models of perception, cognition, behavior, and social interaction formalize psychological theories, and can offer insights into both how people solve challenging everyday problems and how to improve machine performance on these problems. We will consider formalisms for sensory processing, knowledge representation, learning, planning, and decisions, with an emphasis on modeling common problem structures such as statistical learning and probabilistic inference.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Visual Science
description: Each year a different topic in visual science is selected for in-depth review and discussion based on current readings.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Professional Procedures and Survival in Psychology
description: This course provides a forum for presentation and discussion of the basic issues associated with surviving in a professional (particularly, academic) psychology environment. It covers such issues as: 1) how to get a job, 2) how to keep a job, 3) general issues and ethics in professional survival. The course will include the presence of a number of the psychology faculty in topic specific areas (e.g., journal editors from our faculty, faculty sitting on grant review panels, etc.).
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Proseminar in Developmental Psychology
description: The course examines cognitive development through the school-age period and social and personality development from infancy through early adolescence. It begins with an examination of early neurological, sensory, motor, and perceptual functions and then focuses on issues in linguistic and cognitive development. The class will first discuss general developmental theory and methods and then topics such as attachment, temperament, self-concept, aggression, family relations, play, and peers. Students cannot get credit for PSYC 217 if they have already taken PSYC 217A or 217B.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Proseminar in Cognitive Psychology
description: A survey of basic principles and concepts of cognitive psychology. This course is intended to serve as the basic introduction for first-year students. Basic areas include knowledge, memory, thought, perception, and performance.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Writing about Thinking
description: Students will study the cognitive faculties that govern our ability to read for comprehension, along with the opportunities and challenges they create for writers. By reading and discussing primary research, and through feedback on their own writing, students will learn to apply psychological science to the writing activities of psychological scientists (scientific reports, literature reviews, grant proposals, communication with colleagues and students, and writing for the general public).
prereq_raw: restricted to students with the major codes PC76 or PC78 or PC79, or consent of instructor and graduate standing.

title: Proseminar in Social Psychology
description: An introduction to social psychology. Psychology and the law, health psychology, attitudes, emotions, person perception and aggression are some of the topics to be covered.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Proseminar in Sensation and Perception
description: Fundamentals of vision, audition, and other senses. Emphasis will be upon psychophysical approaches to the study of these sensory modalities, as well as some essential aspects of their neurophysiological bases.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Proseminar in Biological Psychology
description: A survey of the functional neuroanatomical, neurodevelopmental, neurophysiological, and pharmacological correlates of psychological phenomena.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Current Directions in Cognitive Neural Systems (CNS)
description: A weekly seminar series focused on understanding recent advances in the relationship between neural systems and behavior using a variety of experimental approaches (single unit recording, comp neuro, evolutionary bio, psychophysics, comparative anatomy, lesion work, psychopharm, fMRI, EEG, TMS, etc.). May be taken for credit twenty-four times.
prereq_raw: graduate standing. S/U grades only.

title: Happiness
description: This course will address the psychology of happiness. The discussions and readings, consisting largely of original research articles, will explore such questions as: What is happiness? How do we measure it, and how do we tell who has it? What is the biology of happiness and what is its evolutionary significance? What makes people happy—youth, fortune, marriage, chocolate? Is the pursuit of happiness pointless?

title: Computational Approaches to Visual Abstraction
description: This course explores the problem of how humans produce and comprehend graphical representations, combining approaches from computational neuroscience, cognitive science, and artificial intelligence.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Tools for Experimental Data Analysis
description: This course will provide an introduction to programming and a set of general data analysis methods that are broadly applicable in many different subdisciplines of psychology/neuroscience. Topics include model fitting, information theory, Fourier analysis, and machine learning. Recommended preparation: Any programming experience will help, but not required. Students may only receive credit for one of the following: PSYC 231, NEUG 231, NEU 231.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Probabilistic Models of Cognition
description: Computational theories of human cognition, particularly Bayesian approaches. Techniques may include directed graphical models; hierarchical models; nonparametric models; probabilistic programming languages. Topics may include decision-making; perception; causal reasoning; categorization; language. Cross-listed with LIGN 228. Recommended preparation: Previous experience with statistics, machine learning, and/or functional programming helpful.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Learning and Motivation
description: Advanced topics in learning and motivation, with special emphasis on current research. May be taken for credit eighteen times.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Evolution of Language
description: This seminar will explore issues related to the evolution of human language, and critically evaluate evidence for the diversity of theories about the topic. Discussions will include the comparative communication and cognition, manual communication, factors surrounding the initial emergence of language, among others.
prereq_raw: graduate standing or consent of instructor.

title: Thought and Language
description: This course will explore the nature of human thought and its relationship to language taking a primarily developmental approach but drawing on contributions from the philosophy of mind and language, linguistics, and anthropology. Each year a different case study will be explored. Past case studies have included concepts, theory of mind, counting, and the logic of thought. Cross-listed with LIGN 232.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Substance Abuse
description: Theory and research on the development, progression, and resolution of substance use and abuse will be reviewed and evaluated. Normal and abnormal patterns of substance involvement will be contrasted across the life span.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Human Rationality
description: The traditional view of rationality is based upon abstract, content-independent rules for behavior. People sometimes violate these rules in a laboratory setting, but the violations are often systematic and appear to reflect adaptation to the environment outside the laboratory. Such findings raise questions about what it means to be rational. Readings will be empirically oriented and cover the areas of deductive reasoning, inductive reasoning, and choice.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: The Primate Brain
description: This course will explore the neural basis of perception, action and cognition in primate cortex. Drawing on recent findings in neuroscience, we will discuss the role of cortex in a range of topics including decision making, object perception and recognition, memory and communication.
prereq_raw: graduate standing or consent of instructor.

title: Programming Web-Based Experiments for Psychology Research
description: This hands-on programming course focuses on the design, implementation, and analysis of online experiments, particularly using Amazon’s Mechanical Turk. Topics include experimental design and counterbalancing, stimulus presentation and timing, response collection using the mouse and keyboard, and debugging experiments written in JavaScript and HTML/CSS. Course work will include individual projects. Recommended preparation: Graduate students who have not programmed at all should speak with the professor beforehand.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Current Directions in Developmental Psychology
description: Advanced seminar concentrating on methods of research and current experimental literature in developmental psychology. May be taken for credit twenty-four times. S/U grades only.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Sound and Music Perception
description: This course deals with perception of sound, particularly music, and focuses on unusual aspects of music perception, including musical illusions and absolute pitch. Relationships between music and language will be explored, and there will be discussions concerning the evolutionary origins of these two forms of communication.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Special Topics in Psycholinguistics
description: Discussion of theories and experiments investigating language production, comprehension, or acquisition.

title: Emotion and Cognition
description: This seminar focuses on the interplay between emotion and cognition. We will consider how emotion influences perception, reasoning, memory, and judgment, and how cognitive processes can have emotional consequences. We will also discuss physiological and neural underpinnings of affective influence and debate more general issues such as emotion and rationality.
prereq_raw: graduate standing or consent of instructor.

title: Learning by Thinking in Children (and Adults)
description: We often learn through observations or from testimony from others. Occasionally, we learn simply by thinking. How do we generate insights in the absence of new information from the external world? This course examines the cognitive capacities involved in learning by thinking, including thought experiments, deduction, analogy, imagination, and learning by explaining. This discussion-based seminar will take a cognitive science approach, emphasizing cognitive development.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Advanced Topics in Applied Behavior Analysis I
description: Research and discussion on selected topics in applied behavior analysis. May be taken for credit five times.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Advanced Topics in Applied Behavior Analysis II
description: Research and discussion on selected topics in applied behavior analysis. May be taken for credit five times.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Advanced Topics in Applied Behavior Analysis III
description: Research and discussion on selected topics in applied behavior analysis. May be taken for credit five times.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Advanced Topics in Learning and Motivation
description: Weekly meetings for graduate students actively engaged in research on conditioning. May be taken for credit multiple times.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Cognitive Neuroscience
description: This is a series of weekly seminars on current trends in neuropsychology. The seminars will deal with the concept of “localization” of function in different parts of the brain and the effects of damage to these parts on cognitive functions such as perception, memory and language. Active student participation will be encouraged in preparing these seminars.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Advanced Topics in Biological Psychology I
description: Research and discussion on selected topics in biological psychology. S/U grades only. May be taken for credit four times.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Advanced Topics in Biological Psychology II
description: Research and discussion on selected topics in biological psychology. S/U grades only. May be taken for credit four times.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Advanced Topics in Biological Psychology III
description: Research and discussion on selected topics in biological psychology. S/U grades only. May be taken for credit four times.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Development and Neurobiology of Theory of Mind
description: Surveys research on people’s everyday attribution of mental states to predict/explain actions, their naïve theory of mind, from developmental and neurocognitive perspectives. Topics include social cognition in infancy and childhood, in autism, and in nonhuman primates, and the brain underpinnings.
prereq_raw: graduate standing or consent of instructor.

title: Delay of Gratification
description: This course will review the research on delay of gratification. We will cover what makes it in general so tough, what situations make it possible, who can do it, and what the implications of this ability are. We will draw from research in social, personality, and animal psychology as well as economics.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Language and Conceptual Development
description: This class will investigate case studies in conceptual development that interact with language acquisition, including domains such as time, space, number, and theory of mind. The approach of the class will be to explore the chosen case study from the perspective of philosophy, linguistics, psychology, anthropology, and comparative psychology, with a particular focus on how conceptual development is affected by the acquisition of language. Cross-listed with LIGN 283.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Functional Construction of the Vertebrate Brain’s Social Behavior Network
description: The vertebrate brain contains a network of strongly interconnected structures that play essential roles in the regulation of social behavior. In this seminar we will read and discuss primary literature that details the structure and behavioral functions of this network.

title: Science of Mindfulness
description: This graduate seminar addresses the science behind mindfulness. Topics include the effects of mindfulness practice on neural processing, psychological well-being, and prosocial behavior. A particular emphasis will be placed on the implications of mindfulness practices/effects on society and education.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Advanced Topics in Language Processes I
description: Research and discussion on selected topics in language processes. S/U grades only. May be taken for credit four times.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Advanced Topics in Language Processes II
description: Research and discussion on selected topics in language processes. S/U grades only. May be taken for credit four times.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Advanced Topics in Language Processes III
description: Research and discussion on selected topics in language processes. S/U grades only. May be taken for credit four times.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Social Psychology and Medicine
description: Concentrates on what psychology has to contribute to the understanding of illness, its treatment, and the social context in which these processes occur. Topics: psychological factors in the etiology and treatment of illness, doctor-patient roles, and communication.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Psychology of Reading
description: This seminar will cover aspects of reading, emphasizing cognitive processes involved in skilled reading. However, learning to read and methods to teach reading will also be discussed. Other topics include eye movements and reading, word recognition, inner speech, context effects, discourse processing, sentence parsing, and dyslexia.

title: Advanced Topics in Behavior Medicine I
description: Research and discussion on selected topics in behavior medicine. S/U grades only. May be taken for credit four times.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Advanced Topics in Behavior Medicine II
description: Research and discussion on selected topics in behavior medicine. S/U grades only. May be taken for credit four times.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Advanced Topics in Behavior Medicine III
description: Research and discussion on selected topics in behavior medicine. S/U grades only. May be taken for credit four times.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Neurobiology of Action
description: This seminar provides an overview of the past and current research on the neurobiology of actions in normal and diseased states such as addiction, Parkinson’s, and other psychiatric disorders.
prereq_raw: graduate standing or consent of instructor.

title: Selected Topics in Cognitive Development
description: An in-depth analysis of selected empirical and theoretical topics in cognitive development. The course will focus on areas where notable progress appears to be taking place in contemporary research.
prereq_raw: graduate standing. Restricted to students with major codes PC81, PC82, PC83, PC84, or consent of the instructor.

title: Introduction to Laboratory Experimentation II
description: Continuation of basic laboratory course designed to introduce first-year graduate students to experimental methods in psychology. The student will select a research topic; do a thorough literature review of the area; design and carry out new, original studies of problems in the selected area; and prepare a final formal report of the study at the end of the spring quarter. This course is required of all first-year graduate students in the department. S/U grades only.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Introduction to Laboratory Experimentation III
description: Final quarter of basic laboratory course designed to introduce first-year graduate students to experimental methods in psychology. The student will select a research topic; do a thorough literature review of the area; design and carry out new, original studies of problems in the selected area; and prepare a final formal report of the study at the end of the spring quarter. This course is required of all first-year graduate students in the department. Letter grades only.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Neurobiology of Learning and Memory
description: This seminar will span the study of learning and memory from an interdisciplinary neuroscience perspective: the goal will be to gain a broad perspective on memory. The course will also touch on dysfunctions of learning and memory such as in amnesia, mental retardation, aging, and Alzheimer’s disease. The course will end with exciting developments in the field, including the possibility of genetic and pharmacological enhancement of memory and intelligence.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Selected Topics in Cognitive Psychology
description: An in-depth analysis of selected empirical and theoretical topics in cognitive psychology. The course will focus on areas where notable progress appears to be taking place in contemporary research.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Selected Topics in Quantitative Methods in Psychology
description: An in-depth analysis and discussion of selected advanced topics in quantitative methods in psychology.
prereq_raw: graduate standing or consent of the instructor.

title: Current Directions in Cognitive Psychology
description: A weekly seminar series focused on understanding recent advances in any area of cognitive psychology. May be taken for credit twenty-four times. S/U grades only.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Selected Topics in Social Psychology
description: An in-depth analysis of selected empirical and theoretical topics in social psychology. The course will focus on areas where notable progress appears to be taking place in contemporary research. May be taken for credit three times.
prereq_raw: graduate standing or consent of instructor.

title: Seminar in Communication and Information Processing
description: S/U grades only.

title: Auditory Neuroscience
description: An in-depth analysis of current theoretical and empirical issues in the neurobiological study of auditory perception and cognition. Example topics include auditory stream segregation, localization, natural stimulus coding, pattern recognition and communication in multiple species.
prereq_raw: graduate standing.

title: Research Practicum
description: Independent research and thesis research. S/U grades only. May be taken for credit fifteen times.

title: Introduction to Public Health
description: This course provides an introduction to the infrastructure of public health; the analytical tools employed by public health practitioners; bio-psychosocial perspectives of public health problems; health promotion/disease prevention; quality assessment in public health; and legal and ethical concerns. Must be taken for a letter grade to be applied to the public health major. Renumbered from FMPH 40. Students may not receive credit for FMPH 40 and PH 40.

title: Introduction to Methods and Ethics in Public Health Research
description: This course will lay a foundation for understanding how to conduct research to answer questions about public health. It aims to teach students why research is done the way it is, what questions we can and can’t answer, and the methodological and ethical limits that must be considered along the way. Students will learn to think critically about the implications and limitations of existing research, and to form their own research questions about public health and the ways to investigate answers.
prereq_raw: PH 40 or FMPH 40.

title: Primary Care and Public Health
description: This course explores historical and current interactions, achievements, and challenges of primary care and public health. It will analyze the impact of common medical conditions such as obesity, diabetes, mental health disorders, and others on individuals, their families, and society. Must be taken for a letter grade to be applied to the public health major. Renumbered from FMPH 50. Students may not receive credit for FMPH 50 and PH 50.

title: Racism as a Public Health Crisis
description: Recently, municipalities around the country have formally declared racism as a public health crisis. What does this mean? We will discuss race, racism, racial health disparities, and the nature of public health crises. Students will practice scientific writing in groups and individually.

title: Learning Sustainable Well-Being: Compassion for Self and Others, a Public Health Perspective
description: This experiential course teaches the art of practicing psychological well-being, based on Eastern and Western approaches (e.g., mindfulness, positive psychology, cognitive therapy, neuroscience, theatre and art), from the perspective of public health. Each week there is a short lecture on a given topic, combined with workshop-style exercises. This course is part of the Learning Sustainable Well-being Program. Visit lsw.ucsd.edu for more information.

title: Exploring Public Health
description: This seminar-style course offers students the opportunity to explore key areas of public health, covering foundational principles across a variety of topics. Subjects range and may include, but are not limited to, career pathways in public health, strategies for maintaining well-being and academic success, mental health awareness and support, sexual health and reproductive rights, mindfulness practices, financial wellness, stress management, and more.

title: Topics in Public Health
description: Selected topics in the field of public health.

title: Medical School Prep 101
description: This course is designed for first-year students and first-year transfer students who are interested in pursuing medicine and becoming physicians. Learn what it takes to prepare for medical school as well as what it takes to be a competitive applicant. We’ll cover everything from academic requirements, timeline, and MCAT to obtaining relevant experiences (i.e., healthcare, service, leadership, and research), letters of evaluation, the fifteen core competencies, and more.

title: Directed Group Study
description: Investigation of public health topics through directed reading and discussion by a small group of students under supervision of a faculty member. Opportunities can also include experiential and research components. May be taken for credit three times.
prereq_raw: completion of thirty units of UC San Diego undergraduate study, a minimum UC San Diego GPA of 3.0, consent of instructor, and a completed and approved Special Studies form.

title: Independent Study
description: Individual undergraduate study or research not covered by the present course offerings. May be taken for credit three times.
prereq_raw: completion of thirty units of UC San Diego undergraduate study, a minimum UC San Diego GPA of 3.0, consent of instructor, and a completed and approved Special Studies form.

title: Epidemiology
description: This course covers the basic principles of epidemiology, with applications to investigations of noninfectious (“chronic”) and infectious diseases. Explores various study designs appropriate for disease surveillance and studies of etiology and prevention. Must be taken for a letter grade to be applied to the public health major. Renumbered from FMPH 101. Students may not receive credit for FMPH 101 and PH 101.
prereq_raw: PH 40 or FMPH 40 and PSYC 60, HDS 60, MATH 11, or COGS 14B, and upper-division standing.

title: Biostatistics in Public Health
description: Fundamentals of biostatistics and basic methods for analysis of continuous and binary outcomes for one, two, or several groups. Includes: summarizing and displaying data; probability; statistical distributions; central limit theorem, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing; comparing means of continuous variables between two groups; comparing proportions between two groups; simple and multiple linear regression. Hands-on data analysis using software and statistical applications in public health. Must be taken for a letter grade to be applied to the public health major. Renumbered from FMPH 102. Students may not receive credit for FMPH 102 and PH 102.
prereq_raw: PH 40 or FMPH 40 and PSYC 60, HDS 60, MATH 11, or COGS 14B, and upper-division standing.

title: Health Behavior and Chronic Diseases
description: This course introduces health behavior concepts through applications to chronic disease prevention. The focus is on smoking, dietary behaviors, and physical activity and is organized around relationships to health, measurement, influencing factors, interventions, and translation to public health practice. Must be taken for a letter grade to be applied to the public health major. Renumbered from FMPH 110. Students may not receive credit for FMPH 110 and PH 110.
prereq_raw: PH 40 or FMPH 40. Restricted enrollment to sophomore, junior, and senior standing.

title: Health Policies for Healthy Lifestyles
description: This course covers the rationale for and effectiveness of policies to influence nutrition, physical activity, and substance use behavior. Policies include legalization, taxation, labeling, produce manufacturing, warning labels, licensing, marketing, and counter-marketing practices and restrictions on use. Must be taken for a letter grade to be applied to the public health major. Renumbered from FMPH 120. Students may not receive credit for FMPH 120 and PH 120.
prereq_raw: PH 40 or FMPH 40 and upper-division standing.

title: Environmental and Occupational Health
description: This core public health course addresses the fundamentals of environmental and occupational health, including identification of hazards, basic toxicology, risk assessment, prevention/protection, and regulatory/control policies. Specific environmental and occupational hazards and relevant case studies will be presented. Must be taken for a letter grade to be applied to the public health major. Renumbered from FMPH 130. Students may not receive credit for FMPH 130 and PH 130.
prereq_raw: PH 40 or FMPH 40, PH 101 or FMPH 101, and upper-division standing.

title: Planning, Conducting, and Reporting Responsible and Ethical Research
description: This course is designed to encourage inquiry of and discussion about regulations, ethical principles, and organizational practices that support the responsible and ethical conduct of research. These concepts will be conveyed using select readings, current events, student-led presentations, and invited guest speakers.
prereq_raw: PH 40 or FMPH 40 and sophomore standing. Renumbered from FMPH 151. Students may only receive credit for one of these courses: PH 151, PH 151R, or FMPH 151.

title: Planning, Conducting, and Reporting Responsible and Ethical Research
description: This course is designed to encourage inquiry of and discussion about regulations, ethical principles, and organizational practices that support the responsible and ethical conduct of research. These concepts will be conveyed using select readings, current events, student-led presentations, and invited guest speakers.
prereq_raw: PH 40 or FMPH 40 and sophomore standing. This is a distance education course. Students may only receive credit for one of these courses: PH 151, PH 151R, or FMPH 151.

title: Qualitative Research for Global Public Health
description: An overview of the role of qualitative research methods in public health. The course will focus on qualitative research as it relates to formative program design, community-based participatory approaches, and as a tool for amplifying voices and elucidating both complex social-ecological processes and internal individual experiences. Throughout the term, students will work in teams to design, conduct, analyze, and report a full qualitative study on a public health topic of their choosing. Must be taken for a letter grade to be applied to the public health major.
prereq_raw: PH 40 or FMPH 40. Restricted enrollment to sophomore, junior, and senior standing. Renumbered from FMPH 155. Students may not receive credit for both FMPH 155 and PH 155.

title: Skills for Health Promotion and Communication
description: This introductory course prepares individuals for public health careers by developing essential communication skills for professional effectiveness. Participants will learn various strategies and techniques for clear and impactful communication across different audiences. The curriculum focuses on creating clear, concise messages and constructing compelling narratives for successful public health initiatives.
prereq_raw: PH 40 or FMPH 40 and sophomore standing.

title: Race, Intersectionality, and Public Health
description: This course will explore the intersection of oppressions based on social identities such as race, ethnicity, socioeconomic class, gender, and citizenship status. This course will introduce the framework of intersectionality, with an emphasis on its use within the field of public health and explore and analyze how race and ethnicity are socially constructed and intersect with identities to influence health behavior and outcomes.
prereq_raw: PH 40 or FMPH 40 and sophomore standing. Renumbered from FMPH 191. Students can’t receive credit for PH 157 if they have already completed FMPH 191 subtitled “Race, Intersectionality, and Public Health.”

title: Clinical Nutrition in Public Health
description: Clinical nutrition is the study of nutrition and diet as related to the prevention and treatment of human disease. The practical and psychosocial aspects of diet modification and food/food product availability are key aspects of clinical nutrition practice, whether individual or community based, irrespective of whether the goal is primary prevention or disease treatment. Students will identify applications and translation of nutritional guidelines and recommendations into behavior in the course. Must be taken for a letter grade to be applied to the public health major.
prereq_raw: PH 40 or FMPH 40. Restricted enrollment to sophomore, junior, and senior standing. Renumbered from FMPH 161. Students may not receive credit for both FMPH 161 and PH 161.

title: Critical Digital Health
description: This course aims to empower students to critically evaluate digital consumer technologies related to health by exploring the social, cultural, and political contexts in which they are designed and used. Students will learn how to evaluate digital consumer tools that are and can be used by the public to promote health and will investigate both the benefits and the unintended consequences of digital health, and the ways in which it can reinforce marginalization.
prereq_raw: PH 40 or FMPH 40 and sophomore standing. Renumbered from FMPH 191. Students cannot receive credit for FMPH 162 if they have already completed FMPH 191 subtitled “Critical Digital Health.”

title: Field Epidemiology and Outbreak Investigations
description: This course consists of a series of practical epidemiological infectious and non-infectious disease paper- and computer-based exercises. Students will have the opportunity to apply their epidemiological and biostatistical skills to real-world situations. The course is highly interactive and challenges students’ knowledge and critical thinking capacities. Students will give presentations, write a scientific abstract and press release, and develop a poster. Must be taken for a letter grade to be applied to the public health major.
prereq_raw: PH 40 or FMPH 40 and PH 101 or FMPH 101. Restricted enrollment to sophomore, junior, and senior standing. Renumbered from FMPH 171. Students may not receive credit for both FMPH 171 and PH 171.

title: Immunizations and Public Health
description: This course addresses fundamentals of vaccine-preventable diseases and immunizations, with an emphasis on resources to maintain public health expertise in a continually evolving field.
prereq_raw: PH 40 or FMPH 40 and sophomore standing. Renumbered from FMPH 191. Students can’t receive credit for FMPH 172 if they have already completed FMPH 191 subtitled “Immunizations and Public Health.”

title: Topics in Public Health
description: Selected topics in the field of public health. Must be taken for a letter grade to be applied to the public health major. May be taken for credit up to three times.
prereq_raw: PH 40 or FMPH 40. Additional prerequisites may be required at instructor’s discretion. Restricted enrollment to sophomore, junior, and senior standing. Department approval required. Renumbered from FMPH 191.

title: Public Health Capstone I
description: This is the first of a two-part capstone series that serves as the culminating experience for the BS in public health (BSPH) majors. Students will integrate the skills and knowledge gained throughout the BSPH program and learn critical elements of public health research and practice. Must be taken for a letter grade to be applied to the public health major.
prereq_raw: PH 40 or FMPH 40, PH 45, PH 101 or FMPH 101, PH 102 or FMPH 102, PH 110 or FMPH 110, and PH 120 or FMPH 120. Department approval required. Restricted to senior public health majors only. Renumbered from FMPH 193. Students may only receive credit for one of the following: PH 193, PH 193R, or FMPH 193.

title: Public Health Capstone I
description: This is the first of a two-part capstone series that serves as the culminating experience for the BS in public health (BSPH) majors. Students will integrate the skills and knowledge gained throughout the BSPH program and learn critical elements of public health research and practice. Must be taken for a letter grade to be applied to the public health major.
prereq_raw: PH 40 or FMPH 40, PH 45, PH 101 or FMPH 101, PH 102 or FMPH 102, PH 110 or FMPH 110, and PH 120 or FMPH 120. Department approval required. Restricted to senior public health majors only. This is a distance education course. Students may only receive credit for one of the following: PH 193, PH 193R, or FMPH 193.

title: Public Health Capstone II
description: This is the second of a two-part capstone series that serves as the culminating experience for the BS in public health (BSPH) majors. Students will interpret and contextualize findings from their projects completed in the first part of the series. Oral and written presentations will focus on disseminating public health information in diverse formats. Must be taken for a letter grade to be applied to the public health major.
prereq_raw: PH 40 or FMPH 40, PH 45, PH 101 or FMPH 101, PH 102 or FMPH 102, PH 110 or FMPH 110, PH 120 or FMPH 120, and PH 193 or FMPH 193. Department approval required. Restricted to senior public health majors only. Renumbered from FMPH 194. Students may only receive credit for one of the following: PH 194, PH 194R, or FMPH 194.

title: Public Health Capstone II
description: This is the second of a two-part capstone series that serves as the culminating experience for the BS in public health (BSPH) majors. Students will interpret and contextualize findings from their projects completed in the first part of the series. Oral and written presentations will focus on disseminating public health information in diverse formats. Must be taken for a letter grade to be applied to the public health major.
prereq_raw: PH 40 or FMPH 40, PH 45, PH 101 or FMPH 101, PH 102 or FMPH 102, PH 110 or FMPH 110, PH 120 or FMPH 120, and PH 193 or FMPH 193. Department approval required. Restricted to senior public health majors only. This is a distance education course. Students may only receive credit for one of the following: PH 194, PH 194R, or FMPH 194.

title: Pedagogy and Learning Apprenticeship
description: Under the supervision of an instructor, undergraduate students gain teaching experience through practical experiences in course management and effective teaching methods. May be taken for credit up to two times.
prereq_raw: a minimum of A– in the course in which the student plans to assist, a 3.0 cumulative UC GPA, and instructor and department approval.

title: Directed Group Study
description: Investigation of public health topics through directed reading and discussion by a small group of students. Opportunities can also include experiential and research components. Study must be under supervision of a faculty member and approval must be secured from the faculty member prior to registering. P/NP grades only. Renumbered from FMPH 198. PH 198 and/or FMPH 198 may be taken for credit a combined total of nine times.
prereq_raw: upper-division standing, completion of ninety units of UC San Diego undergraduate study, a minimum UC San Diego GPA of 2.5, consent of instructor, and a completed and approved Special Studies form.

title: Independent Study
description: Individual undergraduate study or research not covered by the present course offerings. Study or research must be under the direction of a faculty member in the Department of Family Medicine and Public Health and approval must be secured from the faculty member prior to registering. P/NP grades only. Renumbered from FMPH 199. PH 199 and/or FMPH 199 may be taken for credit a combined total of nine times.
prereq_raw: upper-division standing, completion of ninety units of UC San Diego undergraduate study, a minimum UC San Diego GPA of 2.5, consent of instructor, and a completed and approved Special Studies form.

title: Biostatistical Methods I
description: Introductory graduate course on applied statistical data analysis, focusing on multiple linear regression and using the R statistical software. The course addresses issues related to model interpretation, model assumptions, confounding, interactions, testing of coefficients and ANOVA, adjusting for multiple comparisons, heteroscedasticity, model diagnostics, variable selection, prediction error, cross-validation, and resampling via the bootstrap. Renumbered from FMPH 221. Students may not receive credit for PHB 221 and FMPH 221. Must be taken for a letter grade to be applied to the biostatistics degree requirements.
prereq_raw: biostatistics major or program approval.

title: Biostatistical Methods II
description: Intermediate-level graduate course in the analysis of categorical data. Topics include generalized linear models (logistic, Poisson, loglinear models); maximum likelihood and quasi likelihood approaches; model diagnostics, computational approaches and inferential strategies. Both theory and practice will be addressed. Renumbered from FMPH 222. Students may not receive credit for PHB 222 and FMPH 222. Must be taken for a letter grade to be applied to the biostatistics degree requirements.
prereq_raw: successful completion of FMPH 221 or PHB 221 and FMPH 244A or PHB 244A or MATH 281A or program approval.

title: Analysis of Longitudinal Data
description: Analysis of longitudinal data applied to biomedical research. Models for continuous, binary, and count outcomes include the general linear model, linear and generalized linear mixed-effects models, and generalized estimating equations (GEE). Other topics: model building and model selection strategies; types of missing data and dropout; power and sample size calculations. While the focus is on practical statistical modeling, the estimation methodology and computational aspects are explored. Renumbered from FMPH 223. Students may not receive credit for PHB 223 and FMPH 223. Must be taken for a letter grade to be applied to the biostatistics degree requirements.
prereq_raw: successful completion of FMPH 222 or PHB 222 and MATH 281A or MATH 282A or FMPH 244B or PHB 244B or program approval.

title: Biostatistical Methods in Clinical Trials
description: The graduate-level course will cover statistical aspects of clinical trial design, monitoring, analysis, and ethics of human subjects research. Design and computations will be emphasized. Renumbered from FMPH 224. Students may not receive credit for PHB 224 and FMPH 224. Must be taken for a letter grade if applied to biostatistics degree requirements.
prereq_raw: successful completion of FMPH 221 or PHB 221 and FMPH 222 or PHB 222 and FMPH 223 or PHB 223 or program approval. Restricted to PB76, PB77, PB79, PB80, PB81, or consent of instructor.

title: Topics in Non- and Semi-Parametric Statistics and Functional Data
description: The graduate-level course will cover modern statistical inference including non- and semi-parametric statistics, resampling methods, and topics from functional data analysis. Data analysis and computation will be emphasized. Examples of applications discussed include biomedical imaging and wearable device data and their usage in studying health outcomes. Renumbered from FMPH 225. Students may not receive credit for PHB 225 and FMPH 225. Must be taken for a letter grade to be applied to the biostatistics degree requirements.
prereq_raw: successful completion of FMPH 221 or PHB 221, and FMPH 222 or PHB 222, and FMPH 223 or PHB 223 or program approval.

title: Statistical Methods for Observational Studies
description: An introduction to inference and causal modeling for observational data, including propensity score adjustment, inverse probability weighting, instrumental variables, and sensitivity analysis. Data analysis and computation will be required. Must be taken for a letter grade to be applied to the biostatistics degree requirements. Renumbered from FMPH 226. Students may not receive credit for PHB 226 and FMPH 226.
prereq_raw: successful completion of FMPH 221 or PHB 221, FMPH 222 or PHB 222, and FMPH 223 or PHB 223 or program approval.

title: Statistical Learning and Multivariate Analysis
description: This graduate course introduces concepts, methods, and applications of statistical learning and multivariate data analysis, including prediction, classification, regularization, decision trees, principal components analysis, and clustering. Data analysis will be emphasized. Renumbered from FMPH 227. Students may not receive credit for PHB 227 and FMPH 227. Must be taken for a letter grade to be applied to the biostatistics degree requirements.
prereq_raw: successful completion of FMPH 221 or PHB 221 and FMPH 222 or PHB 222 or program approval.

title: Statistical Computing
description: The goal of this course is to give students a useful toolkit for handling statistical computations in R. This includes being able to write legible and robust code, debug R functions, run computer simulations, find ways to speed up calculations, encapsulate code and documents in R packages, and have some sense of issues that impact real-world computation. Students may not receive credit for PHB 228 and the FMPH 291 taught with the same title.
prereq_raw: FMPH 221 or PHB 221, and FMPH 222 or PHB 222, and FMPH 244B or MATH 281A or PHB 244B. Restricted to biostatistics majors or department approval.

title: Biostatistics Rotation
description: This practicum provides hand-on experience with biomedical research and data analysis. Working within a specific biomedical domain (e.g., cancer, genomics, or physical activity research), students will conduct original data analysis and prepare or substantially contribute to a final project report. Renumbered from FMPH 241. PHB 241 and/or FMPH 241 may be taken for credit for a combined total of five times.
prereq_raw: successful completion of FMPH 221 or PHB 221 and FMPH 222 or PHB 222; biostatistics major only.

title: Advanced Topics in Biostatistics
description: Biostatistics elective courses will be taught under this course heading. Courses will have a varying focus each year/quarter. Topics will include random field theory and image analysis, advanced statistical computing, Bayesian methods, and others. May be taken for credit up to three times. Renumbered from FMPH 242. PHB 242 and/or FMPH 242 may be taken for credit for a combined total of three times. Must be taken for a letter grade to be applied to the biostatistics degree requirements.
prereq_raw: successful completion of FMPH 221 or PHB 221 and FMPH 222 or PHB 222 or program approval.

title: Practicum in Biostatistics A
description: This is the first in a sequence of two core courses for the MS degree in biostatistics. The course takes advantage of the extensive involvement of the program faculty in collaborative and interdisciplinary work within the life sciences. Didactic instruction on best practices in statistical collaboration. Under supervision, the students will participate in applied, real-life projects stemming from the research and collaborations of the faculty in the Division of Biostatistics. Renumbered from FMPH 243A. Students may not receive credit for PHB 243A and FMPH 243A.
prereq_raw: successful completion of FMPH 221 or PHB 222 and FMPH 223 or PHB 223. Restricted to major code PB76.

title: Practicum in Biostatistics B
description: This is the second in a sequence of two core courses for the MS degree in biostatistics. The course takes advantage of the extensive involvement of the program faculty in collaborative and interdisciplinary work within the life sciences. Didactic instruction on best practices in statistical collaboration. Under supervision, the students will participate in applied, real-life projects stemming from the research and collaborations of the faculty in the Division of Biostatistics. Renumbered from FMPH 243B. Students may not receive credit for PHB 243B and FMPH 243B.
prereq_raw: successful completion of FMPH 243A or PHB 243B. Restricted to major code PB76.

title: Foundations in Biostatistics A
description: This course will mainly focus on probability theory and mathematical statistics, which are essential building blocks for more advanced inference tools. Topics include probability theory, (multivariate) random variables, functions of random variables, expectations, variance and moments, common families of distributions, properties of a random sample, statistics and sampling distribution, convergence of a sequence of random variables. Renumbered from FMPH 244A. Students may not receive credit for PHB 244A and FMPH 244A. Must be taken for a letter grade to be applied to the biostatistics degree requirements. Restricted to major code PB76.

title: Foundations in Biostatistics B
description: Continued overview of mathematical foundations in biostatistics. The second course in a two-course series. Maximum likelihood theory. Sufficiency, efficiency. Hypothesis testing and confidence intervals. Robustness and power. Large-sample properties of commonly-used estimators and tests. Renumbered from FMPH 244B. Students may not receive credit for PHB 244B and FMPH 244B. Must be taken for a letter grade if applied to biostatistics degree requirements.
prereq_raw: FMPH 244A or PHB 244A, restricted to major code PB76.

title: Applied Survival Analysis
description: Survival analysis has applications in biomedicine, economics, and engineering. It deals with the analysis of time-to-events data with censoring and truncation. This course discusses concepts and methods, comparing survival distributions, proportional hazards and other regression models, competing risks data, and design of survival studies. The emphasis is on semiparametric approaches, and material is drawn from recent literature including machine learning methods.
prereq_raw: FMPH 244B or PHB 244B.

title: Health Policy, Technology, and Public Health
description: This course provides an overview of the US health policy landscape. It addresses the development of explicit health policies to promote certain health behaviors, policies aimed at public health safety, and policy issues related to emerging health and biomedical technologies. Renumbered from FPM 290. Students may not receive credit for FMPH 277 and FPM 290.
prereq_raw: must be enrolled in the UC San Diego/SDSU Joint Doctoral Program in public health (PU75, PU76, and PU77), biostatistics major (FM77), or consent of instructor.

title: Biostatistics Journal Club
description: This is a biweekly, structured journal club. Students will critically read assigned articles. During meetings, students work in groups to discuss specific questions regarding the assigned article, and are asked to present their answers to the class. Renumbered from FMPH 290. PHB 280 and/or FMPH 290 may be taken for credit for a combined total of six times. Restricted to major codes PB76 or PB77.

title: Biostatistics Seminar Series
description: Through a combination of in-person and virtual seminars on Zoom, students will gain insight into current research projects presented by invited speakers. Additionally, students are provided with the opportunity to participate in lunch discussions and one-on-one meetings. All MS students in biostatistics, and biostatistics PhD students in their third year and above are highly encouraged to enroll quarterly (except for summer). May be taken for credit up to twelve times.
prereq_raw: FMPH 290 or PHB 280. Restricted to PB76 and PB77 majors.

title: Introduction to Mixed Methods Research
description: This course will provide an introduction to the definition, design, and practice of mixed methods research. Mixed methods approaches are becoming increasingly common in many research areas, especially in public health because of the combined use of qualitative and quantitative data sets. This course will teach you to meaningfully integrate the two and takes an applied focus.

title: Epidemiology of Aging
description: This course encompasses a range of topics related to aging including the demography of aging, hallmarks of biological aging, physiological reserve and resilience, physical and cognitive function, major chronic diseases of aging (diabetes, kidney disease, heart disease, cancer, osteoporosis, fracture, Alzheimer’s disease, and related dementias), multimorbidity, and epidemiology of healthy aging.

title: Epidemiology of Aging Lab
description: The objectives of the epidemiology of aging lab supplement are to familiarize students with aging cohorts, prominent biases, and methodological approaches to addressing them; commonly used statistical methods; and common areas of epidemiological research in aging populations.

title: Grant Writing for Public Health
description: Students will review funded and nonfunded grant proposals for different types of NIH awards, with an emphasis on R01 research awards. Students will have an opportunity to have their own proposals reviewed by instructors and classmates. The instructor will prepare a research proposal with help from the students.

title: Life Course Research
description: This course examines life course research for health sciences. Emphasis will be placed on methodologies employed to estimate cumulative effects from earlier life exposures and biologic pathways to describe risks on health and disease across the life course.

title: Introduction to Genetic Epidemiology
description: The course introduces the fundamental concepts, principles, and methods in genetic epidemiology. The course reviews terminology used in genetics, introduces principles of population and human genetics, and provides an overview of the use of molecular and genetic methods in utilized genetic epidemiologic and clinical research. This includes the study designs used to identify the genetic basis of Mendelian and complex traits and diseases.

title: JDP Public Health Seminar
description: This course combines didactic instruction, interactive sessions, and student presentations. Topics cover study design, ethics, data analysis and management techniques, and qualitative research will be presented.

title: Epidemiology Practicum
description: Students will explore an epidemiologic research question by reviewing relevant published literature, and then design and conduct appropriate data analysis using a preexisting dataset.

title: Scientific Writing
description: Students will learn the principles of scientific writing, review examples of scientific literature, and then complete a manuscript suitable for publication based on their research project.

title: Scientific Presentation
description: Students will learn the principles of scientific presentations for the classroom and for scientific meetings (both oral and poster presentations). Students will then prepare and deliver presentations based on their research project.

title: Cultural Perceptions about Health and Disease
description: This course takes an interdisciplinary look at the relationship between culture and health in diverse sociostructural contexts.

title: Addressing Health Equity through Policy
description: Public health policy is what public officials within government, and by extension the citizens they represent, choose to do or not to do about public health problems. This course provides an overview of the U.S. health policy landscape and addresses the development of explicit health policies to promote certain health behaviors, policies aimed at public health safety, and policy issues related to emerging health and biomedical technologies.

title: Scale Development for Behavioral Health Measurement
description: Course will present theory and methods for developing scales to assess public health-related constructs (e.g., physical, mental, and social well-being).

title: Practicum in Global Health and Health Behavior
description: Students will learn about grant writing, project management, preparation of manuscripts for publication and presentations for scientific meetings, and also work individually with a faculty mentor in preparing manuscripts using data from a specific health behavior intervention.

title: Introduction to Qualitative Research Methods
description: The aim of this course is to introduce graduate students to the strengths and appropriate use of qualitative research and analysis methods, with specific application to public health research and policy. The course will use a combination of didactic, group, interactive, and applied techniques to teach knowledge and skills relevant to qualitative research. Lecture will present on the theory and ethical use of qualitative methods.

title: Special Topics in Public Health
description: Topics of special interest in public health. Topics may vary from quarter to quarter.

title: Independent Study in Public Health
description: Individual graduate study or research not covered by present course offerings. Study or research must be under the direction of a faculty member in the School of Public Health and approval must be secured from the faculty member and track director prior to registering.

title: Dissertation Research in Public Health
description: Public health doctoral program dissertation research units.

title: Teaching Methods in Public Health
description: This course is for graduate students wanting to develop skills and knowledge to become a teaching assistant or as preparation for an academic teaching career. The course covers the practice and theory of educating others, curriculum and instructional design, and teaching best practices.

title: Special Topics in Public Health
description: Independent study for biostatistics graduate students in the Herbert Wertheim School of Public Health and Human Longevity Science. Study of special topics for graduate students under the direction of a faculty member. Exact subject matter to be arranged in individual cases. Restricted to PB76 and PB77 majors. May be taken for credit up to twenty-one times.
prereq_raw: department approval required.

title: Dissertation Research
description: Dissertation research for students who are advancing or have advanced to candidacy. May be taken for credit up to twelve times. Renumbered from FMPH 299. PHB 299 and/or FMPH 299 may be taken for credit for a combined total of twelve times.
prereq_raw: department approval required.

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
description: Students will understand principles of measurement of clinical data, recognize data types, and determine statistical methods for analysis of a given dataset. They will gain experience in preparing a clinical dataset for analysis. Students will learn basic data visualization, statistical testing and inference, and statistical modeling with R.
prereq_raw: must be enrolled in MPH program (PB75, PB87, PB88, PB89, PB90, and PB91) or program approval. Renumbered from FMPH 400. Students may not receive credit for both FMPH 400 and PH 400.

title: Introduction to Epidemiology
description: This course provides a foundational understanding of principles and methods used to study the distribution and determinants of health and disease in populations. Topics include study design, data collection, measures of disease frequency, and risk assessment. Through lectures and small group discussions, students learn to critically evaluate epidemiological research, understand the ethical considerations in conducting epidemiological studies, and recognize common sources of bias and confounding.
prereq_raw: must be enrolled in MPH program (PB75, PB87, PB88, PB89, PB90, and PB91) or program approval. Renumbered from FMPH 401. Students may not receive credit for both FMPH 401 and PH 401.

title: Introduction to Health Behavior
description: This course provides an opportunity to explore the theoretical issues and current methodologies related to understanding and influencing health behavior change in diverse populations. The course will focus on the social, behavioral, and biologic determinants of health on the individual, interpersonal, community, institutional, and policy levels. The examples of application of theories to determinants and intervention research and disparities in health behavior and outcomes are covered.
prereq_raw: must be enrolled in MPH program (PB75, PB87, PB88, PB89, PB90, and PB91) or program approval. Renumbered from FMPH 402. Students may not receive credit for both FMPH 402 and PH 402.

title: Public Health Research Methods
description: This course will focus on fundamental concepts in research design and measurement to understand methodological considerations in quantitative and qualitative scientific studies in public health and be able to critically evaluate public health research. Emphasis will be on creating testable hypotheses, designing a hypothetical study to test the hypothesis, and assessing methods of measurement.
prereq_raw: must be enrolled in MPH program (PB75, PB87, PB88, PB89, PB90, and PB91) or program approval. Renumbered from FMPH 403. Students may not receive credit for both FMPH 403 and PH 403.

title: Introduction to Environmental and Occupational Health
description: This course examines the relationship between human activities, the environment, and health. It explores how environments affect well-being, focusing on hazards from workplaces and contamination. It also addresses personal and societal behaviors impacting environmental health and reviews strategies to mitigate negative human effects at individual and community levels.
prereq_raw: must be enrolled in MPH program (PB75, PB87, PB88, PB89, PB90, and PB91) or program approval. Renumbered from FMPH 404. Students may not receive credit for both FMPH 404 and PH 404.

title: Introduction to Health Policy
description: This course will introduce students to health policy making and the organization and financing of health services in the United States, enhance their understanding of the historical and political context of health policy, and enable them to develop strategies for analysis of health policy issues. The course aims to convey not just specific facts, but to help students develop the ability and confidence to assess current health policy issues in a thoughtful, comprehensive, and rigorous manner.
prereq_raw: must be enrolled in MPH program (PB75, PB87, PB88, PB89, PB90, and PB91) or program approval. Renumbered from FMPH 405. Students may not receive credit for both FMPH 405 and PH 405.

title: Scientific Writing
description: This course will prepare students for scientific writing in a variety of contexts. These may include scientific abstracts and research summaries, plain language summaries, op-eds, community engagement, and using LLMs. The course will incorporate group projects as well as individual assignments.
prereq_raw: must be enrolled in MPH program (PB75, PB87, PB88, PB89, PB90, and PB91) or program approval. Renumbered from FMPH 406. Students may not receive credit for both FMPH 406 and PH 406.

title: Health Behavior Interventions
description: This course focuses on critical analyses of health behavior theories and their applications to interventions in multiple fields, such as (but not limited to) nutrition, cancer, and physical activity. The course will prepare students to design, plan, implement, and evaluate health behavior interventions covering individual and population approaches to behavior change.
prereq_raw: must be enrolled in MPH program (PB75 and PB87) or program approval and successfully completed PH 402. Renumbered from FMPH 410. Students may not receive credit for both FMPH 410 and PH 410.

title: Program Optimization and Evaluation
description: This course covers study designs to iteratively optimize and evaluate public health programs such as a proof-of-concept trial, randomized controlled trial, sequential multiple assignment randomized trial, factorial screening trial, microrandomized trial, stepped wedge trial, single case experiments, and nonrandomized study designs. The course includes a philosophical grounding on why evidence is important and what underlying assumptions undergird “evidence-based practice.”
prereq_raw: must be enrolled in MPH program (PB87, PB90, and PB75) or program approval and successfully completed FMPH 402 or PH 402, and FMPH 403 or PH 403. Renumbered from FMPH 411. Students may not receive credit for both FMPH 411 and PH 411.

title: Health Promotion and Communication
description: This course is focused on the principles of health promotion and health communication, examining the societal impact and needs, behavioral change theory, and study designs to develop and evaluate interventions. Effective communication techniques used to promote behavior change, disseminate evidence, and communicate risk in today’s multimedia world are highlighted, including cultural tailoring. Students serially develop and apply these strategies in the design of a public health campaign of their choice.
prereq_raw: must be enrolled in MPH program (PB75, PB87, and PB90) or program approval and successfully completed FMPH 402 or PH 402. Renumbered from FMPH 412. Students may not receive credit for both FMPH 412 and PH 412.

title: Ethics in Public Health Research and Practice
description: The first section of this course provides an introduction to key frameworks and concepts relevant to public health ethics. The remaining part of the course considers ethical dilemmas across resource allocation and distributive justice, individual rights versus the common good, health promotion and disease prevention, free markets versus social justice, research ethics, emerging public health technologies and interventions, and public health and the environment.
prereq_raw: must be enrolled in the MPH program (PB91, PB87, PB88, PB90, and PB75) or program approval. Renumbered from FMPH 413. Students may not receive credit for both FMPH 413 and PH 413.

title: Advanced Epidemiologic Methods
description: This course will provide an in-depth overview of modern epidemiologic concepts, including fundamentals of causal inference; quantitative measures of occurrence, association, and effect; epidemiologic study design; epidemiologic data analysis; sources of bias in epidemiologic studies; and design and analytic strategies for the evaluation and mitigation of bias in epidemiologic studies.
prereq_raw: must be enrolled in MPH program (PB75 and PB91) or program approval and successfully completed FMPH 401 or PH 401. Renumbered from FMPH 415. Students may not receive credit for both FMPH 415 and PH 415.

title: Cardiovascular Disease Epidemiology
description: This is an MPH-level course designed to introduce topics in cardiovascular disease epidemiology using the following definition of epidemiology as a guide: Epidemiology is the study of the distribution and determinants of health-related states or events in specified populations, and the application of this study to the control of health problems. As such, the course provides an overview of the prevalence, incidence, and key risk factors for major cardiovascular diseases.
prereq_raw: must be enrolled in MPH program (PB75 and PB91) or program approval and successfully completed FMPH 401 or PH 401. Renumbered from FMPH 417. Students may only receive credit for one of these courses: PH 417, PH 417R, or FMPH 417.

title: Cardiovascular Disease Epidemiology
description: This is an MPH-level course designed to introduce topics in cardiovascular disease epidemiology using the following definition of epidemiology as a guide: Epidemiology is the study of the distribution and determinants of health-related states or events in specified populations, and the application of this study to the control of health problems. As such, the course provides an overview of the prevalence, incidence, and key risk factors for major cardiovascular diseases.
